page.lettertext:
fol.164r
Belgia 15
91
12 June To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: June:
May it please yo
r
good L. I am newly come to
Doccum
w
ch
is from
Groeningen
half a daies journey, & heer I have
mett w
th
e
Councel of State
. The
Count
is come w
th
all
his forces, & is alredy encamped w
th
in a litell english mile
of
e Towne of Groeningen, It is thought that by this
he hath stopped all
e passages, that
ey cannot be
relieved w
th
provisyon of vittailes, But wee cannot yet
learne what store ys in
e Towne,
Verdugo
hath ernestly
endevoured to put in a garrison, w
ch
they w
th
in w
th
stand
very stoutly, & they saie it is a cause
t
they ar greatly
devided. Uppon
e first arrival of
e Count, the Ennemy
was stricken w
th
so great a terror, as they abandoned p
nt
ly
15 places of strengthe, of w
ch
e greatest
te were sconces &
fort
t
might well have abidden
e shott of
e Cannon.
Howbeyt Verdugo is encamped between us &
e towne, but
und
r
savegard of
e Canon & by common conjecture w
th
some
1400 men. It is thought hee ys in hope to entertayne
us
t
waie, till
e Towne may be succored w
th
furder
forces from
e
Duke,
who as wee are enformed is coming
thetherward in
son w
th
5000 foote, & 600 horse, whether
it be to come directly thether, or to invade some other
place, while wee are buisied in these quarters, wee cannot
yet understand. But
e Count hath left behinde in
Guelderland
&
Utrecht,
15 ensignes of foote, & 1/2 a cornet to
empeache his attempt
. And yet
e Frisons are so
forward in
e furtherance of this
attempt
enterprise, as they
have renforced
e army w
th
as many new enseignes: so as
yet wee do recken that they come at
e least that are in
these quarters to 12000 horse & foote. Because I know
not very well how my l
re
s from hens wilbee safely
convayed, by reason of my going so farr into
e countrey
& because they must passe through many mens hand
, I do
therefore purpose according as matter & messengers ar
p
nt
ed, to send yo
r
L. sometimes
e double copye of a letter
fol.164v
To my L T
re
r
12 June 1590
Belgia: 1591: June:
And so I take my humble leave. From Dock
u
12 June. 1591.
postscript.
Before I had shutt up my letter, we had further intelligence from
Count Maurice, & from sondry other places, that
e Duke
of Parma for certayn hath passed
e Rhine & doth
advance his coming w
th
all possible dilligence, whither
we shall attend & encounter w
th
him, whertoo as yt seemeth
Count Maurice is bent, or shall take some oth
r
cowrse
by retraict, or entrenching, as
e Councell ys enclined, who
think
e state of
e countrey wilbee oth
r
wise hazarded, I
cannot yet signify, but they determine this morning to
go toward
e army, to confer w
th
Count Maurice. This
is ev
r
y mans hope, that
e Army of
e Duke shalbee
destitute of meanes, to continew long in these quarters for
want of vittailes &c./.
